newsitem.title: UK: Eurotunnel spells out post debt-deal future.
newsitem.headline: Eurotunnel spells out post debt-deal future.

text.p: Channel Tunnel operator Eurotunnel thanked shareholders on Friday for backing its debt restructuring deal and said it was confident of improving its performance after being freed from its financial shackles.

Eurotunnel's board spelled out its post debt-deal vision at a shareholder meeting in London the day after its momentous extraordinary general meeting in Paris where shareholders gave near-unanimous backing to the 8.6 billion pounds ($14.5 billion) debt restructuring plan, thereby avoiding possible bankruptcy.
"Yesterday's decision was of historic proportions," said George Malpas, co-chairman who described Thursday's make-or-break meeting in Paris as "noisy and contentious."
Patrick Ponsolle, group executive chairman, said Friday's meeting saw "a cowed and quiet audience" in comparison to the high emotions of Thursday's six and a half hour marathon in Paris.
After receiving stinging attacks from some shareholders in Paris, British shareholders provided a contrast for the Eurotunnel board.
"I'd like to congratulate the board," said one British investor. "They must have had a very difficult time over the last few months. It's nice to see they still have some hair left."
The restructuring package covered 8.6 billion pounds in junior debt and cut shareholders equity to 54.5 percent from 100 percent, giving creditor banks 45.5 percent.
Bill Dix, managing director of the Le Shuttle tunnel service for lorries and cars, told the meeting that the future looked more promising and stable.

He said Eurotunnel was aiming for 50 to 55 percent of the cross-Channel market share by the year end and said the group was also enjoying a premium over ferry prices which he saw as a key development.
Finance Director Richard Shirrets said the next key milestone will be passed by the group when it breaks even.
"The performance so far this year makes us confident that objective will be met."
The group's three-year plan aims to have a 45 percent increase in traffic for the Shuttle by 1999.
Eurotunnel sees revenues rising by 15 percent by that year and operating costs falling by 13 percent to 316 million pounds. Operating profits are seen at 215 million by 1999.

Outlining risks which remain once the debt-deal has finally been cleared by the remaining banks later this autumn, Eurotunnel said there was continued uncertainty over whether P&O Plc and Stena would merge their cross-Channel ferry routes and reduce capacity.
Reduced capacity would cut future risk of price wars with the tunnel.
Another risk would be if the planned high-speed link between London and Folkestone was delayed beyond its 2004 launch.
That link is seen as key to boosting traffic into the tunnel. The last threat is a change in economic conditions which could impact on traffic.
But the group said its new financial stability made it better able to face the future.
